Please read and follow the expectations and formatting for commit messages.
Added file close() for cleanup which was missing earlier. Single line changes only. So pushed them together
why is close() required?  I thought we generally relied on RAII for closing files?

We had some issues seen during the system test, where the file read writes are made back to back for a long time. We saw some race conditions that the next operation was attempted before the file is closed after the previous operation. this resulted in corrupting the file content. So added the close() and is_open() calls explicitly.

So, you had issues without close() and then when you tested, those issues went away when you added close()?  That makes no sense, considering that answers like this say that explicit close() calls are not required.

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/748014/do-i-need-to-manually-close-an-ifstream

I'm having trouble understanding why the behavior would be any different, given that.  Can you elaborate?
Please wrap the body at 72 characters

Glad to see this stuff being moved forward;  Can we talk a little bit about the long term plans here?  Having this kind of code that directly manipulates the filesystem in bmcweb breaks the OpenBMC architecture in kind of unfortunate ways.  Per the other handlers, the business logic for this should be going into its own daemon and schema, which IBM can maintain, and bmcweb can just call the dbus interface to like we would anything else, which would remove me from most of the management console lock code reviews, and let ibm implement their business logic however they wanted 😊

Can we discuss timeframes on when/how that changeover can happen?  Considering that we're doing non-trivial business logic updates in this patch series, it seems like a good time to put together a long term plan for this code.

Sure. I would need Gunnar also to share his views. There is no dbus calls in this ibm_management_console use-cases. This is completely within bmcweb. We have the compiler flag since day 1. If there is any other better way to branch this out at upstream master, we can do that

Ed, We had an internal discussion with the design team. By 2Q 23 or 4Q 23 we either remove this code under /ibm/v1 or move to a D-Bus model as mentioned by you. 

Does that sound ok ?

So, about 12-18 months out from any changes here?  Cool.  Seems like a lower priority then.  How do we want to handle the business logic updates until then?  Just wait until we get the architecture corrected, then merge the business logic updates when the IBM daemon is complete?

+1
IBM namespace, is domain of the IBM

I was the one that suggested we need to make sure it is a realistic timeframe and we can meet it and we ended up at 12 -18 months. I know Sunitha's team is going to work on this here soon so I would call it "medium priority". I think that timeframe is more realistic than a timeframe like end of the year. 

> Just wait until we get the architecture corrected, then merge the business logic updates when the IBM daemon is complete?

Could we merge these business logic changes for now? We can add an issue or a TODO in the code or both saying this is changing by the dates Sunitha mentioned.

I think not accepting anymore business logic as we close in on that date is reasonable. I think commenting out the option with a notice to remove if we pass that date is also reasonable. 
https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/meson_options.txt#L174
I think there is options if we don't address this. Would like a reasonable amount of time to address this though.

I guess I'm struggling a little bit.  I'm reading the above as "We can't even start this for 12-18 months, but we can do a bunch of other stuff right now" which really kinda feels like a push off, I'm sure that wasn't the intent.  I really do think you guys would move faster with your own application.  There's things like the an RAII object needing to explicitly call close that I don't understand, but because it's in a user facing application, i kind of do need to understand it if it's truly a problem we need to fix elsewhere (I really suspect it's not).  If it's in a separate app, go wild.  I kind of assumed this management console stuff was dead, given that I haven't seen many updates to it.

Is there a path where we can do incremental progress, so you can get your patches merged, and we can make progress toward a better end solution, where IBM can maintain their application and interfaces the same as we would any other application.  Something like:
First business logic change on bmcweb
phosphor-dbus-interfaces defined and pushed
second business logic change on bmcweb
Repo requested and created
third business logic change in bmcweb
daemon created and ready for bmcweb port.

That way you can make progress, and in the end, we end up with a solution that looks like the rest of the system.

> I think commenting out the option with a notice to remove if we pass that date is also reasonable. 

That doesn't seem reasonable to me;  If I have to do that, we've failed.  Even when I did it in the virtual media case, it didn't have the desired effect, so it's not clear that pattern helps people to contribute.

> There's things like the an RAII object needing to explicitly call close that I don't understand, but because it's in a user facing application, i kind of do need to understand it if it's truly a problem we need to fix elsewhere (I really suspect it's not)

I can continue investigating to find that 'elsewhere'. Probably we could not recreate the original issue and this change really was not the 'fix'? But i don't see any harm in calling these file APIs explicitly. I can move these back to the old code if you strongly feel that there could be issues if i call the close() explicitly. 

> I kind of assumed this management console stuff was dead, given that I haven't seen many updates to it

These APIs are used by IBM systems, and we had not pushed any code upstream recently due to other priority work-items.

> we can make progress toward a better end solution

The use-cases in this file does not have any dbus interactions. They are contained within the bmcweb only. So there will be no dbus change in future for this.

I can see there is https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/meson_options.txt#L181 google-api compiler flag implementing /google/v1 at https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/include/google/google_service_root.hpp. I will check more on what is different in that api implementations.

> > There's things like the an RAII object needing to explicitly call close that I don't understand, but because it's in a user facing application, i kind of do need to understand it if it's truly a problem we need to fix elsewhere (I really suspect it's not)
> 
> I can continue investigating to find that 'elsewhere'. Probably we could not recreate the original issue and this change really was not the 'fix'? But i don't see any harm in calling these file APIs explicitly.

It's extra code, and if our RAII model (suggested by cpp core guidelines) is broken in the std library, then this is important.

> I can move these back to the old code if you strongly feel that there could be issues if i call the close() explicitly. 

I don't feel strongly either way, I'd like to understand why an explicit close() changes the code paths at all.  RAII should be covering us here, and the std library documentation backs that up, so we need to at least understand it.

> 
> > I kind of assumed this management console stuff was dead, given that I haven't seen many updates to it
> 
> These APIs are used by IBM systems, and we had not pushed any code upstream recently due to other priority work-items.
> 
> > we can make progress toward a better end solution
> 
> The use-cases in this file does not have any dbus interactions.

My point is that it should be calling dbus.  This code is doing blocking filesystem calls to a filesystem that could lock up (ie, not read only tmpfs that common_errors.md documents as ok and basically never blocks).  If the RW filesystem has any issues, bmcweb will effectively brick, which is a stability issue.

> They are contained within the bmcweb only. So there will be no dbus change in future for this.
> 
> I can see there is https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/meson_options.txt#L181 google-api compiler flag implementing /google/v1 at https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/include/google/google_service_root.hpp. I will check more on what is different in that api implementations.

Google V1 calls dbus for OEM-specific behavior, as does the Intel crashdump stuff which predates ibm/v1.

> "We can't even start this for 12-18 months, but we can do a bunch of other stuff right now"

I think it was meant to convey complete in 12-18 months. 

I think we have a solution where most of this (ibm/v1/) goes away but we are still discussing. We can bring forward a more complete plan later with any phosphor-dbus-interfaces defined for anything that does stay.

I guess I would prefer these go in, but if we want to hold off on merging these until there is more progress on moving to proper OpenBMC architecture (bmcweb call the dbus interface), I am okay with that. These patches are already in our fork downstream, I think Sunitha was just trying to get them upstream.

> These patches are already in our fork downstream, I think Sunitha was just trying to get them upstream.

Yes. Thats right.

We would want to retain the implementation at https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/34208 at upstream master, and will remove the configFile and lock implementations in an years time.

> I think it was meant to convey complete in 12-18 months. 

Gotcha.  That changes the math a little;  Lets continue this patchset and get it in, and see how it goes.   I'm still waiting on some other questions to be answered in other threads, then I think this patchset can merge.

> where most of this (ibm/v1/) goes away

Cool.  Love to see the thoughts for that when it's ready.

I thought the corp specific namespaces were left to the owners of the name space.

I will ask an honest/direct question, as long as the ibm stuff does not affect upstream bmcweb, why do we really care?

Because it does affect upstream bmcweb, and the code is currently checked into upstream bmcweb.  In terms of commits recently, you'll notice I'm a large contributor to a file that I don't and can never use.

> I thought the corp specific namespaces were left to the owners of the name space.

Corp specific namespaces implement corp-specific functionality, that doesn't mean that they get to ignore the openbmc core principals like "create a well-structured dbus interface" and "Don't do blocking IO calls in an async reactor", both of which this code does.

Ack

As agreed, the features which does not use 'well-structured dbus interface' will be removed by next year first quarter
I'm still waiting on an explaination of why explicitly calling close() has any effect on an raii object that will immediately go out of scope.

readfile is not raii, it is just a stack variable. The stack variable going out of scope will not trigger the destructor, because it is not a shared/unique_ptr.

As a solution, stdplus provides a managedFd that might fit your needs, and provide a raii. However, bmcweb rarely requires use of stdplus.

https://github.com/openbmc/stdplus/blob/master/include-fd/stdplus/fd/managed.hpp#L28
Yep, iostream is definitely RAII, the stdplus version exists as a simpler version (that doesn't require streaming)
I still see a file.close() added here? If that is still needed, please add that to the commit msg.
Thanks Gunnar. I missed it. Now removed that readfile.close()
In the future, please make this two commits.  These are two independent things that have almost nothing to do with one another.
